Hazardous xenobiotic organic compounds are introduced into the environment via wastewaters generated by human activities and industry. As a result of new legislation (Water Framework Directive, 2000), increased attention is being paid to the fate and mass balance of a number of dangerous pollutants during the conventional activated sludge treatment process. Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and p-xylene (BTEX) or volatile Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) such as naphthalene are commonly emitted into the environment due to their ubiquitous presence in fuel and petroleum products (Melcer, 1994). These xenobiotic compounds figure on the priority substances list established by the European Water Framework Directive because of their hazardous properties for the environment and their CMR (Cancer, Mutation and Reproduction) properties (An, 2004; Luch, 2005; Farhadian et al., 2008). The aerobic biological process is one of the best technologies available for treating industrial wastewaters. Bioremediation is an efficient tool for transforming the compounds to less hazardous or non-hazardous forms with less input of chemicals, energy and time (Ward et al., 2003).
